comments.commentBody:
In any dispute, if both sides agree to be reasonable and civil, they'll usually reach a positive conclusion. Not long ago, I got glasses that were entirely unlike those described. When I went to talk with the shop owner she took a posture that was both defensive and hostile. It inclined me to want to pursue every possible remedy against her business.

A shame. Many doctors (and small businesses like the one I described) claim to do good but actually treat their customers like trash.

Ned: '...Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof...'

Abercrombie & Fitch is not part of the government, besides which no one was stopping this woman from practicing her religion.

I can't help but indulge myself in stereotyping a Los Angeles reader using "DD" for a handle. Is your career as a Victoria's Secret model threatened by this decision, and before you've paid off the surgical augmentation to your professional credentials?

She never said she didn't wish to comply -- she was never presented with the dress code nor was she asked if she could or would comply -- the decision was made based on her scarf, without asking her anything about her manner of dress.

So far as I am aware, there is no religion that mandates its adherents be fat.

Of course, there seems to be no proscription on, or shortage of, fat-headedness among those unacquainted with the simple language of, or the most basic jurisprudence interpreting, the First Amendment.

As Justice Scalia said, "This is an easy case."

This is "I am SUCH a victim!" taken to absurd heights.

If an employer has a dress code, especially an employer that sells fashion items and requires the applicant to have contact with the public, and the applicant doesn't wish to abide by it for ANY reason, go apply somewhere else.

Next thing you know, Victoria's Secret will be forced to hire old fat sales girls dressed as if the there are no mirrors in their house, and the light in their closet burned out last week.

Srnini: "...And giving a job to someone wearing a hijab is not accommodating anything..."

It is against the company's dress code, so this woman was asking for special treatment.

Now every religious fundamentalist will do the same and the country will be ever more worse for it.

Sometimes you can be too close to the issue to really see it, J.

Sure, many young Muslim women say they feel happier, closer to their religion/culture, etc.
But from an American perspective, where we celebrate assimilation, an overt Islamic dress code is a kind of poke-in-the-eye, coming as it does from a religion that advocates jihad and makes headlines every day for its extreme lack of tolerance.

Rosa Parks got on the bus and sat in the front on purpose. As did the Greensboro Four. Her motivation is not a matter of law; the motivation of A&F in NOT hiring her was. They could have said she was ugly or not pleasant spoken. That would have been valid. But they chose her head covering, a religious symbol, and that is illegal.

Religious freedom and, to a certain extent, its usual expression by its believers, are closely held values by Americans. The Justices correctly interpreted the laws that are on the books that reflect those values. Yarmulke, Hijab, etc - protected. Ugly? Not.

If you are a citizen of this country you have access to the democratic process and can attempt to change these laws. That's the awesome bit about this whole thing.
Because the Constitution and the Bill of Rights say so. What country do you belong and under what rock did you go to school?
Be advised, a company cannot refuse to hire some based on age.  Age can only be a factor if it prohibited someone from completing a required physical task (lifting 50 pounds, etc).

Like Scalia said, "This is really easy."  You cannot discriminate against hiring someone for something tied to their religion, which in this case the head scarf pretty clearly was.  A&F will still be able to discriminate against potential hires base on looks or age or height or chest size or whatever other attributes they want to promote among their employees.  What is really interesting is the larger sentiment that is being expressed in the comments section, that perhaps we shouldn't be protecting religious freedoms more aggressively than other freedoms.  Non-believers have probably experienced more persecution by religious people in America than religious people have been persecuted by non-believers.
They specifically told her. Did you not read the article
I'm going to reserve judgment about how humorless and self-important Caitlyn Jenner is until I see/hear more of her. But self-important? No argument there.

.
Martin,

Deb's "Insider" blog post mentions four puzzles.

And these Insider people don't get their money's worth: They're not having discussions or posting video links in the Comments.
Reasonable, perhaps, but banning the hijab is not reasonable. It's a bleedin' head scarf!

Hypocrisy?

Without which no religion would survive?

The United States (and more specifically here the Supreme Court) should be applauded for its stance on the Muslim faith. This stance is much more in keeping with the values of Islam than that of the vast majority of Muslim countries.
Its also more committed to respecting the Muslim faith than the vast majority of Muslim countries.
I promise you that this woman's religion has in no way been foisted upon you. You do NOT have to go to work tomorrow wearing a head scarf. The constitution guarantees it.
Have you been anywhere in the Southern United States recently? I mean anywhere?
Cherries and  apricots made a very pleasant cold drink simply poured over some ice and diluted with 2 parts of water, and the fruit was nice to nibble on too.

I completely disagree and I am surprised to find someone from our fine city who is so ignorant of American history and law.  Freedom to practice one's religion -- in daily life -- is the "free exercise" part of the First Amendment, just as important as the "separation of church and state" part.  It is illegal to discriminate against someone on the basis of religion in employment and has been for quite a long time.  A&F could just as easily have said that black skin conflicts with their "look policy" or their "East Coast collegiate style" and we all know exactly what they would have meant by that.  There is no requirement in American law to limit one's expression of faith to a small pendant.  Our law is actually much more clear than French law, which leaves many openings for covert racism and is regularly used to harass Muslims even when they are complying with French law.  There is nothing "ostentatious" about observing the rules of your religion -- for you to perceive as a threat or an attack is odd indeed.  Muslims do not hear headscarves in order to proselytize or promote their religion to others -- it is a personal expression of piety.  The fact that Western Christians no longer have religious articles of clothing that are worn daily does not mean that Western Christianity is a better system.  I hardly find being preached at by a religious fundamentalist Christian as I'm crossing the street a "reserved" behavior but it is also protected by the First Amendment.

Tim: '...Religious freedom is so important we made it the topic in the Constitution's First Amendment...'

As is freedom from religion.

No one is forbidding this woman from practicing her religion. It is A & F who is being forced to give her special treatment because of it, as she and only she will be allowed to wear a head covering, while the other salespeople will not.

Next time you are interviewed by the New York Times you can ask that they refer to you as Mrs or Miss and explain that it is part of your deeply held religious beliefs.  If they fail to comply, you can try to sue them, but you are not likely to prevail as there is no protection from discrimination based on religion during media interviews that I know of.

Because people are complex
And full of contradictions.Can a conservative Christian or Sikh work at A and F?She was 17 at the time.She has the right to practice her religion and be an American teenager at the same time

This is not a new path by the court.  Freedom to and from religion has already been upheld by the Supreme Court.  Religion gets special treatment because it is one of the first freedoms enshrined in our Constitution, while the desire (for example) to wear a Hawaiian shirt every day because you like it is not.  If, however, you claim that wearing a Hawaiian shirt is part of a deeply felt spiritual practice, even if that practice is entirely personal and not part of any recognized religion, the Supreme Court will likely be on your side.
"Too many still seem fixated on tort reform, even when evidence shows us that it don’t seem to do much to reduce the practice of defensive medicine."  ...it don't seem to do much? Ow!

Only 6% of doctors get sued for malpractice? I would have thought it would be higher than that, much higher. We must be afraid of our doctors in America.

I see 4 different doctors for different health issues in any given year, and only one of them is a good communicator, who runs a good practice. This man has something figured out that the others don't. Part of it is that he hires good people to work for him. Both his nurses and his office staff are polite, on-time, and caring. One of my other doctors has a crummy nurse who has repeatedly not listened to me about my prescription needs, and claimed she knew nothing about the mail order pharmacy I use despite the fact that I have spoken with her previously about it. I realized it flows from the top down and that her boss, my doctor, doesn't listen to me either, and has a phony, condescending consulting room manner with me. I'm done with him and his nurse now.

I think a lot of it is that most doctors are arrogant people who think they know it all when they don't. They have been at the top of the professional class of white-collar professions since the rise of the American Medical Association in the past 100 years, riding on the reputation of science. Good medicine is as much art as it is science because it involves people, I.E., us patients.
Whey? Jenner was a he when he made those records.
